body:
A lot of improvement regarding speedier completion has gone into the clangexp branch which will be merged into master at some point in the future when [issue 126](https://github.com/wbond/sublime_package_control/issues/126) in Package Control is fixed.

For anyone who have slow completions in your projects, I recommend checking out the clangexp branch manually for now. If something is broken in it, please let me know and also be aware that you can toggle the fast completions on and off with the default keybinding alt+d,alt+f and if nothing is found by the fast completions it'll fall back to the old libclang completions. So worst case you'll have to toggle fast completions off temporarily, and best case you get much faster completions. As a reference in one of my project it takes less than 13 ms for a simple class member completion that took 5.35 seconds (!) before, or ~0.5s vs 7.25s when just pressing ctrl+space on an empty line.

Here are the steps needed to check out the clangexp branch:

```
# Uninstall SublimeClang via Package Control if you had it installed this way before
# Go to your Packages directory in a terminal
git clone git://github.com/quarnster/SublimeClang.git
cd SublimeClang
git checkout clangexp
git submodule update --init
# There are now prebuilt versions for Windows x86/x64 and OS X x86/x64, but for Linux or if you want to build your own version:
cd src
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
# If you are using Windows and are building with nmake you might have to copy the dll file manually with "copy *.dll ..\..\" 
# Restart sublime text
# Hopefully you'll get as much of an improvement as I do.
# Btw if you don't have cmake installed, the sources needing compilation is just a single .cpp file,
# so you can probably just as well manually invoke the appropriate compiler command to generate
# a shared library on your platform.
```

It'll still fall back to libclang's completions for templates though. Once merged with master it'll have precompiled shared libraries for Win32/64 and OS X 32/64. Linux users will have to compile it themselves (but there's a pop up dialog telling you about that part if the lib isn't found).

Not sure if anyone other that myself has tested the clangexp branch so it might suffer from issues I've not seen. But for anyone trying, please give me your feedback and open up issues where it's not behaving as expected.

Last time I tried it wasn't working so well but it seems usable now, I'll give it a deeper look.
It still seems to fall back to slow completion often for some reason.
Small tests where the completion falls back to the slower would be appreciated.

I just got the clangexp branch working on Windows... it's a bit of a pain to compile libcache.dll right now, and my fork isn't really in a state where it should be pulled (the libclang.dll is now from clang trunk because I needed the .lib file to link against), but if anyone wants to try it: https://github.com/jfaust/SublimeClang

Completion speed is definitely much improved in the clangexp branch, though I haven't played around with it too much

Yep I'm trying it out and it's definitely a lot faster!
It seems that clang's completion is reparsing the cpp+includes each time it's fired, no wonder it's slow...

Until now, the only case I could corner that would always fall back to the slow completion is if you type "this->" in a cpp file, the home-made parsing couldn't find the class name since it searches for the class definition in the file. Nothing I use often anyway, direct member completion works perfect.

Just wanted to say, this is great and it fixes my only real complaint about SublimeClang! With even medium-sized projects, it was starting to become a hinderance because of the speed -- I would be able to see characters I typed slowly print across the screen. But it was otherwise very useful!

This branch fixes things very nicely. Now I have no real complaints about SublimeClang at all. Thanks for the cool software!
